articles.title: Quantum simulations that once needed supercomputers now run on laptops
articles.summary: A team at the University at Buffalo has made it possible to simulate complex quantum systems without needing a supercomputer. By expanding the truncated Wigner approximation, they’ve created an accessible, efficient way to model real-world quantum behavior. Their method translates dense equations into a ready-to-use format that runs on ordinary computers. It could transform how physicists explore quantum phenomena.
articles.content:
Picture diving deep into the quantum realm, where unimaginably small particles can exist and interact in more than a trillion possible ways at the same time.

It's as complex as it sounds. To understand these mind-bending systems and their countless configurations, physicists usually turn to powerful supercomputers or artificial intelligence for help.

But what if many of those same problems could be handled by a regular laptop?

Scientists have long believed this was theoretically possible, yet actually achieving it has proven far more difficult.

Researchers at the University at Buffalo have now taken a major step forward. They have expanded a cost-effective computational technique known as the truncated Wigner approximation (TWA), a kind of physics shortcut that simplifies quantum mathematics, so it can handle systems once thought to demand enormous computing power.

Just as significant, their approach -- outlined in a study published in September in PRX Quantum, a journal of the American Physical Society -- offers a practical, easy-to-use TWA framework that lets researchers input their data and obtain meaningful results within hours.

"Our approach offers a significantly lower computational cost and a much simpler formulation of the dynamical equations," says the study's corresponding author, Jamir Marino, PhD, assistant professor of physics in the UB College of Arts and Sciences. "We think this method could, in the near future, become the primary tool for exploring these kinds of quantum dynamics on consumer-grade computers."

Marino, who joined UB this fall, began this work while at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz in Germany. His co-authors include two of his former students there, Hossein Hosseinabadi and Oksana Chelpanova, the latter now a postdoctoral researcher in Marino's lab at UB.

The research received support from the National Science Foundation, the German Research Foundation, and the European Union.

Taking a semiclassical approach

Not every quantum system can be solved exactly. Doing so would be impractical, as the required computing power grows exponentially as the system becomes more complex.

Instead, physicists often turn to what's known as semiclassical physics -- a middle-ground approach that keeps just enough quantum behavior to stay accurate, while discarding details that have little effect on the outcome.

TWA is one such semiclassical approach that dates back to the 1970s, but is limited to isolated, idealized quantum systems where no energy is gained or lost.

So Marino's team expanded TWA to the messier systems found in the real world, where particles are constantly pushed and pulled by outside forces and leak energy into their surroundings, otherwise known as dissipative spin dynamics.

"Plenty of groups have tried to do this before us. It's known that certain complicated quantum systems could be solved efficiently with a semiclassical approach," Marino says. "However, the real challenge has been to make it accessible and easy to do."

Making quantum dynamics easy

In the past, researchers looking to use TWA faced a wall of complexity. They had to re-derive the math from scratch each time they applied the method to a new quantum problem.

So, Marino's team turned what used to be pages of dense, nearly impenetrable math into a straightforward conversion table that translates a quantum problem into solvable equations.

"Physicists can essentially learn this method in one day, and by about the third day, they are running some of the most complex problems we present in the study," Chelpanova says.

Saving supercomputers for the big problems

The hope is that the new method will save supercomputing clusters and AI models for the truly complicated quantum systems. These are systems that can't be solved with a semiclassical approach. Systems with not just a trillion possible states, but more states than there are atoms in the universe.

"A lot of what appears complicated isn't actually complicated," Marino says. "Physicists can use supercomputing resources on the systems that need a full-fledged quantum approach and solve the rest quickly with our approach."

articles.personality_title: New method lets laptops simulate complex quantum systems once needing supercomputers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Quantum systems involve tiny particles that can exist in many states at once. Studying these systems usually requires powerful supercomputers because the math is very complex and grows harder as the system gets bigger.

**What happened** – Researchers at the University at Buffalo improved a technique called the truncated Wigner approximation (TWA). They made it simpler and able to handle real-world quantum systems where energy changes happen. Their new method turns complicated math into easy-to-use steps that run on a regular laptop, not a supercomputer. This work was published in September in the journal PRX Quantum.

**Impact** – This change means physicists can explore many quantum problems faster and without expensive supercomputers. It makes studying quantum behavior more accessible and saves big computers for only the hardest problems. Scientists say users can learn the method quickly and start solving difficult cases within days.

**What's next step** – Researchers will likely use this method to study a wide range of quantum systems that were too complex before. It may also speed up discoveries in physics and technology by letting more people run simulations on everyday computers.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new, simpler method now allows complex quantum simulations to run on regular laptops, making advanced research faster and more accessible.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle méthode permet aux ordinateurs portables de simuler des systèmes quantiques complexes auparavant réservés aux superordinateurs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les systèmes quantiques impliquent de très petites particules pouvant exister dans de nombreux états en même temps. Étudier ces systèmes demande généralement des superordinateurs puissants, car les calculs sont très complexes et deviennent plus difficiles à mesure que le système grandit.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'Université de Buffalo ont amélioré une technique appelée approximation de Wigner tronquée (AWT). Ils l'ont rendue plus simple et capable de gérer des systèmes quantiques réels où l'énergie change. Leur nouvelle méthode transforme les calculs compliqués en étapes faciles à utiliser sur un ordinateur portable ordinaire, sans besoin de superordinateur. Ce travail a été publié en septembre dans la revue PRX Quantum.

**Impact** – Ce changement permet aux physiciens d'explorer de nombreux problèmes quantiques plus rapidement et sans superordinateurs coûteux. Cela rend l'étude du comportement quantique plus accessible et réserve les gros ordinateurs pour les problèmes les plus difficiles. Les scientifiques disent que les utilisateurs peuvent apprendre la méthode rapidement et commencer à résoudre des cas complexes en quelques jours.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs utiliseront probablement cette méthode pour étudier une large gamme de systèmes quantiques auparavant trop complexes. Cela pourrait aussi accélérer les découvertes en physique et en technologie en permettant à plus de personnes d'exécuter des simulations sur des ordinateurs courants.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une méthode nouvelle et plus simple permet désormais de réaliser des simulations quantiques complexes sur des ordinateurs portables ordinaires, rendant la recherche avancée plus rapide et accessible.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo método permite a laptops simular sistemas cuánticos complejos que antes requerían supercomputadoras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los sistemas cuánticos involucran partículas muy pequeñas que pueden existir en muchos estados al mismo tiempo. Estudiar estos sistemas normalmente requiere supercomputadoras potentes porque las matemáticas son muy complejas y se vuelven más difíciles a medida que el sistema crece.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Buffalo mejoraron una técnica llamada aproximación de Wigner truncada (TWA). La hicieron más simple y capaz de manejar sistemas cuánticos reales donde la energía cambia. Su nuevo método convierte las matemáticas complicadas en pasos fáciles de usar en una laptop normal, sin necesidad de una supercomputadora. Este trabajo se publicó en septiembre en la revista PRX Quantum.

**Impacto** – Este cambio permite a los físicos explorar muchos problemas cuánticos más rápido y sin supercomputadoras costosas. Hace que estudiar el comportamiento cuántico sea más accesible y reserva las grandes computadoras para solo los problemas más difíciles. Los científicos dicen que los usuarios pueden aprender el método rápidamente y comenzar a resolver casos complejos en pocos días.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores probablemente usarán este método para estudiar una amplia gama de sistemas cuánticos que antes eran demasiado complejos. También podría acelerar los descubrimientos en física y tecnología al permitir que más personas realicen simulaciones en computadoras comunes.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un método nuevo y más simple ahora permite que simulaciones cuánticas complejas se ejecuten en laptops normales, haciendo la investigación avanzada más rápida y accesible.
